conversation.content: [startled] Oh, I didn't expect anyone else to be up here at, um, three in the morning. Are you... are you okay? You've been sitting there for a while, I think.
Depends on your definition of okay.

[hesitantly] I mean, I get it. New place, everything feels off. I've been transferring schools since I was twelve, so, uh, the whole disconnected feeling is pretty much my default state at this point.
[softer] Those look old, the photos you're holding. Family or, um, friends from before?
Before what?

[carefully] Before whatever brought you up to this roof at three AM with a box of memories and that look on your face. The one that says you're, I don't know, trying to figure out if you still belong anywhere.
Hmm. Pretty perceptive.
Look, I know we just met, well, technically we haven't even met yet, but, um, I recognize that particular brand of lost. [sighs] Been there more times than I can count.
These are from my first year here, back when I thought I knew exactly who I was gonna be, you know? Pre-med, straight A's, the whole ambitious package. [bitter laugh]
[gently] And now you're what, junior year? Senior? Something must've changed pretty dramatically to have you up here contemplating, er, whatever you're contemplating.
Failed organic chemistry twice. My advisor basically told me to find a new dream because this one's dead. Three years of my life just... gone.
Ouch. That's, um, that's rough. Though, I mean, three years isn't gone exactly, it's just... redirected maybe? Like, you still learned things, met people, grew as a person or whatever.

[wistfully] You sound like my therapist, except she charges two hundred an hour to say that. These photos though, they're from when everything made sense, when I actually believed I was meant for something specific.
Who says you aren't?
Reality. [exhales]

[thoughtfully] You know what? Every school I've transferred to, I've had to completely reinvent myself. Not because I wanted to, but because, well, I had no choice. And honestly, it's terrifying every single time.
[quietly curious] How many schools total? And, um, why do you keep having to move? Military family or something?

Six schools in ten years. My mom's job, she's a corporate restructuring specialist, which basically means she goes wherever companies are falling apart. [rueful chuckle] Ironic, right? She fixes broken things for a living but never stays long enough to see if they actually heal.
[softer] That's actually kind of beautiful in a really messed up way. Maybe that's what we all are, just... temporarily fixed, waiting for the next thing to break us open again. [long pause]
[warmly] I'm Jordan, by the way. And for what it's worth, I think being lost means you're still looking for something, which is, um, better than giving up entirely, right?

scenario: A transfer student discovers their new dorm roommate sitting alone on the rooftop at 3 AM, staring at old photographs and questioning whether they should drop out.
